kdoc.title: Cardiac Simulator
kdoc.notes:
![Cardiac Simulator Screenshot](Cardiac.png) [Full article on the Cardiac](https://www.cs.drexel.edu/~bls96/museum/cardiac.html)
The Cardiac Computer was a learning tool in the late 1960s from Bell Labs, it was used to show aspiring Computer Scientists how a computer processor works, and believe it or not, but it is still relevant til this day, as modern computers still work and process data in a similar manner, just with many many more op codes.
[GitHub Repo of source](https://github.com/kveroneau/Cardiac) [Windows binary](Cardiac.zip)
Here is the full source code for the Cardiac Computer Simulator:
Below is the entire **.LFM** file for the form:
You can find some sample program decks in the link above, or you can use this one here which is shown in the screenshot:

section.name: Cardiac Assembler
section.notes: In order to make creating programs for the Cardiac computer easier, I created an Assembler, also in Object Pascal. It is in the Bitbucket repo, and also below.

This program is able to take an assembly program for the Cardiac and assemble a proper deck of cards for the Cardiac computer to run. It has two bootloaders, the original `bootstrap`, and a new `bootloader` created by me. Below is an example assembly program for the Cardiac that the above program will assemble.
section.example:
# This deck1.txt converted over to ASM format. # Lines which start with a hash are comments.
# Here we declare our variables in memory for use. var count = 0 var i = 9
# This is needed to add the special Cardiac bootstrap code. bootloader
# Program begins here. CLA STO $count label loop CLA $i TAC $endloop OUT $count CLA $count ADD STO $count CLA $i SUB STO $i JMP $loop label endloop HRS
# End of program. end
